Definition: a generally used class of NZ steam locomotive

Notes: Google search Mar 2006: only NZ citations found(4).

Definition: to be jack, to be aware (this is purely Aust.: check and prob. delete).

[EDD 6 Police officer or detective in plain clothes. War. Part. : Jack : cant ca 1865, becoming genl. Austr. sl. ca 1910 pl. Jacks 1. Milit Police Austr and NZ Military 1914-1918 (very rare in sg) 2. hence in NZ cant `the police' - 1932.] W Ramson: phs. in Aust, I think : usual word John, applied to institutional inspectorial officials, esp. if uniformed.
Notes: Usu. the jacks (pl.), not freq. and often humorous, = police (man) (cf John).

Definition: A look: `have a jack at this'; have a jack at, to have a look at, cf jack nohi.
Notes: (?mainly prisoners') (informal) ->1981 Feb Avondale College (Auckland) Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection) give us a jack: ?perve =?look (?or = masturbate) ca1985 Auckland Tui O'Sullivan Adolescents, particularly young Maoris, occasionally say jocularly have a haki.

Definition: (? West Coast) (native) crow (usu. saddleback, cf jackbird).

Notes: [AND (1889) Jack of 1892] this may be purely Aust: if so delete (also at X-ref jack off).]

Definition: In address or ref. (nickname). a. (hist, between combatants in NZ Wars) Cf WW1 and WW2 George, Jack Maori, and use of Jacky.
A nosey parker; a look-round, a squiz ?jack a look + nohi nosy (rhymes boy or nor he); see also nohi.
Notes: ca1987 p.c. Peter Janssen, Heinemann: heard at Huntly (among other North Island places) Known also to P. Ranby, Auckland. What are you doing. I'm having a Jack nohi (meaning: I'm having a look, a poke round; being nosey). What's that over there. Let's go and have a Jack nohi. ca1940's-1950's North Auckland (p.c. Barry Mitcalfe 1951) A regular (Jack) Nohi.

1989 Charles Ransom notes: Jack stud or rafter - While these terms were not found elsewhere, OED notes use of jack "as denoting things that are smaller or lighter than the real ones" and there are several such constructions.

Definition: to arrange, engineer, wangle (cf. jack-up n.); to rebuild, fix up, reorganise, etc.
a rough hotel or boarding house
the spear of a timber-jack or screw-jack
a trick, a wangle, an underhand deal.

Notes: 1953 Wellington There seem to be far too many jackings-up going on for the thing [election] to be fair.

Definition: a Turk(ish soldier), Turkish soldiers collectively
a Boer (cf. Jack (Maori)); poss. influenced by rhyme with Jacky Raw; and also common use of jack : Jack tar; =police etc.
Either of two types of hard, usually green, fine-grained minerals, used as an ornamental stone or in jewellery; in New Zealand formerly, now occasionally, applied to greenstone; =greenstone.
short for Jade Stadium, the former Lancaster Park sports stadium in Christchurch (to 2006? only)
Notes: also Jade Stade, National Radio discussion, 23/06/2005

Definition: Occas. used for greenstone (but is not greenstone check).
an Aucklander (acronym of Just another f***ing Aucklander)
an orange-coloured candy ball with a centre of chocolate

Notes: note double f in spelling (cf. Jafa and Jafaphobia); 'triangle' in citation is what?

Definition: party, esp. booze-party, =booze session [not drug], see also on the (drunk).

Notes: -->[OEDS2 - [Sc. North Eng and US dial.] sense nf S/1.] [P8: (610) Jag v. 3. To depress; get on the nerves: NZ: 19C - earlier 20C. GB Lancaster Sons O' Men 1904.] -->1957 Frame Owls Do Cry 17
ca1945 (R. Mason) esp. trampers' (? rhyme on fagged, shagged, + on the jag)

Definition: The usual expression in NZ: be jake, chiefly constr: she's jake, she'll be jake, etc. -->(? 1918) 1933 Acland All right, comfortably placed (since 1918?)
Notes: 1981 Auckland Secondary Teachers College(Goldie Brown Collection) she'll be jake

Definition: To fight (orig. to challenge to a fight behind the school jakes), cf jakes.
Notes: (local secondary schools) 1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 30A JAKE, I WILL JAKE YOU [BEHIND JAKES]

Definition: Good of a kind; honest, true

Notes: from Jake Heke (Jake the Muss) q.v.

Definition: a Jehovah's Witness (from initials J.W. (cf. Jay Dub) and the fact that they were reputed to get down on the jam or have an unnatural appetite for jam.) -->ca1941-5 R.C.
a light usually rubber or plastic sandal with a thong between the big and second toe (also called thong; in Britain usually called flip-flop). [probably a blend of Japanese and sandal]
Notes: [OEDS2.] A pair of simple sandals with two straps joined and fitted between two toes; see also thong [from a trade name]. 1981 Feb Avondale College (Auckland) Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection) jandals 1981 Rangiora High School (Goldie Brown Collection) jandalls: in the dict.

Definition: A ship girl who specialises in Japanese seamen.
premium snapper exported whole and chilled to Japan, or of a grade acceptable for export
Notes: from the polystyrene bin used to pack premium snapper for export to Japan

Definition: Prunus salicina, a species of plum originating in China, in contrast to European plum - Prunus domestica.
Notes: Jim writes: many of the commoner plum varieties in NZ, e.g. omega, black Doris, sultan are Japanese plums.

Definition: 2.25 l. flagon, formerly half-gallon container of (or for) beer (occas. wine); cf. flagon, half-G
1. Any of numerous often climbing shrubs of the olive family, having usu. very fragrant flowers. 2. In NZ, esp. a native climber with small, creamy flowers, often called Maori jasmine.

Notes: (obs criminals') 1932, Nelson Baylis (in a private letter; N.Z.); 1944, M and B (Aus.), extant. -->1984 17 M E107Pakuranga Coll. 33 JAY: HAVE A JAY [illegal activities: =?: ?jar]

Definition: Junior Chamber of Commerce, a member of the Junior Chamber, a service organisation of young businessmen.

Definition: A humorous var. of jee whizz, a euphemism for Jesus!

Definition: short for jelly sandals (brightly coloured plastic sandals)

Definition: chocolate-coated ice-cream tipped with jelly on a stick
A device for unrolling rolls of wire along a fenceline
[fencing] an implement upon which wire is wound for easy feeding out.
To understand; to catch on (to); to tumble to.
in phr. take a jerry to: to take a tumble to, to jerry (q.v.).
an introduced shrub, related to poroporo, bearing poisonous berries, scarlet or orange when ripe.

a randomly-picked machine bet race selection

an edible tree-fungus, once a commercial export to China.
an attractive gecko of widely varying colours and patterns; main populations are in Otago and Banks Peninsula, and east side of Southern Alps.

Definition: A squid fisherman who uses a jig to catch squid.
Something that moves by jigging along.
Notes: (railwaymen's): R. Mason notes (p.c.); came across but did not note different terms used for this in England and the U.S.. Jigger invariably used in NZ; CC Ransom notes: The US layman's term is hand-car, but most have motors now; and the railwaymen's term is doubtless something shorter. Contrast trolley.

Definition: A frame on wheels to carry wounded.
Here the ref. is to an old motorbike and side-car, prob. a gen. but obsolesc. colloquial term (cf buzzer), and not to the rail jigger.
Any handy implement or instrument Gen. sense `thingummyjig'.

Notes: ca 1951 R. Gilberd Letter. A theodolite is sometimes referred to as an instrument but more often as a `jigger'.

Definition: A person who travels by jigger n1..

Notes: ca1890 Jane Morison, house-maids in Blenheim hotels ca1935 familiar or euphemistic

Definition: a 'people's bank' proposed by Jim Anderton, Deputy Prime Minister, in 1999 (established as Kiwibank)
Notes: also as Jimmy's Bank in 2000 cit.

Definition: a new chum (abbrev. of Jimmy Grant).

a drink taken alone (in a public bar).

Notes: cf. jigger. (Contrast catamaran, a sledge contraption.) (DNZE main entry is at janker)

Definition: A cry, often Joe! Joe! to greet newcomers or strangers to a diggings, and especially a warning cry to herald the approach of authorities.

Notes: 1839 W. Wakefield Diary [Ruth Fletcher's Note. There is no fish known by this name, but the Fisheries Office consider that the Joe-fish is probably the Javelin fish.]

Definition: A complete fool; a dullard; cf Joe n rhyming on cunt, a complete fool; a disliked person). ca 1945 esp. a regular joe-hunt. eg `What do you thing I am? A Joe Hunt. Do the bloody job yourself.' `The boss makes regular Joe Hunts out of all the junior staff.'

Constr. the Joe Morgans, the horrors. 1928 Smyth J. of H. 87 You would give anybody the Joe Morgans.

a cart with rubber tyres used on farms.

a policeman, cop (cf. John, Jack, John Dunn)

a wasting disease in sheep, cattle and deer

Notes: [?Nonce term:? ref. to John Lee + John = shithouse; or an ? actual term at time.]

Definition: Truth weekly, from owner John Norton (cf John Norton).
Any place, building, organisation (esp. phs, a cheap eating-house, hash-house or brothel).
a family house owned by the spouses in common.

meaning particular to a type of fishing operation that existed between the declaration of the 200-mile exclusive economic zone in 1978, and 1986 when the QUOTA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM was introduced; during which foreign fishing vessels entered into business arrangments with New Zealand companies to gain the right to fish the zone.
applied to various animals or objects

person, the usual NZ term for bloke, fellow, chap, cove, etc (usu. used by and about male humans, but occas. of animals, and occas. (? from ca 1970) of and by women), cp bloke, cove (cf sport 1897, a follower of sport).
Notes: [AND now chiefly Aust and NZ 1. fellow 1810 2. transf (dog) etc 1914.] See also Kiwi joker. Baker NZ Slang (1941) does not mention it. cf 1947 Beattie E.R 66 [commenting on `Character'] When I heard such a [runholder] described as `a character', I took it as meaning eccentricity ..... A man who played practical jokes was `a joker'.
